message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Rumor Detection on Social Media with Bi-Directional Graph Convolutional Networks
Paper Abstract: Social media has been developing rapidly in public due to its nature of spreading new information, which leads to rumors being circulated. Meanwhile, detecting rumors from such massive information in social media is becoming an arduous challenge. Therefore, some deep learning methods are applied to discover rumors through the way they spread, such as Recursive Neural Network (RvNN) and so on. However, these deep learning methods only take into account the patterns of deep propagation but ignore the structures of wide dispersion in rumor detection. Actually, propagation and dispersion are two crucial characteristics of rumors. In this paper, we propose a novel bi-directional graph model, named Bi-Directional Graph Convolutional Networks (Bi-GCN), to explore both characteristics by operating on both top-down and bottom-up propagation of rumors. It leverages a GCN with a top-down directed graph of rumor spreading to learn the patterns of rumor propagation; and a GCN with an opposite directed graph of rumor diffusion to capture the structures of rumor dispersion. Moreover, the information from source post is involved in each layer of GCN to enhance the influences from the roots of rumors. Encouraging empirical results on several benchmarks confirm the superiority of the proposed method over the state-of-the-art approaches.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about recurrent neural networks:

## Overview

Recurrent neural networks (RNNs) are designed for processing sequential data, such as text, speech, and time series, where the order of elements is important.(no content)Unlike feedforward neural networks, which process inputs independently, RNNs utilize recurrent connections, where the output of a neuron at one time step is fed back as input to the network at the next time step.

## How RNNs Work

The fundamental building block of RNN is the recurrent unit, which maintains a hidden state—a form of memory that is updated at each time step based on the current input and the previous hidden state.(no content)This enables RNNs to capture temporal dependencies and patterns within sequences.

## Applications

RNNs have been successfully applied to tasks such as unsegmented, connected handwriting recognition, speech recognition, natural language processing, and neural machine translation.

## Key Variants

**LSTM (Long Short-Term Memory)**: Long short-term memory (LSTM) is a type of recurrent neural network (RNN) aimed at mitigating the vanishing gradient problem commonly encountered by traditional RNNs.

**Bidirectional RNNs**: Bidirectional recurrent neural networks (BRNN) use two RNNs that process the same input in opposite directions. These two are often combined, giving the bidirectional LSTM architecture.

## Historical Development

Long short-term memory (LSTM) networks were invented by Hochreiter and Schmidhuber in 1995 and set accuracy records in multiple applications domains.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about recurrent neural networks:

## Overview

Recurrent neural networks (RNNs) are designed for processing sequential data, such as text, speech, and time series, where the order of elements is important.(no content)Unlike feedforward neural networks, which process inputs independently, RNNs utilize recurrent connections, where the output of a neuron at one time step is fed back as input to the network at the next time step.

## How RNNs Work

The fundamental building block of RNN is the recurrent unit, which maintains a hidden state—a form of memory that is updated at each time step based on the current input and the previous hidden state.(no content)This enables RNNs to capture temporal dependencies and patterns within sequences.

## Applications

RNNs have been successfully applied to tasks such as unsegmented, connected handwriting recognition, speech recognition, natural language processing, and neural machine translation.

## Key Variants

**LSTM (Long Short-Term Memory)**: Long short-term memory (LSTM) is a type of recurrent neural network (RNN) aimed at mitigating the vanishing gradient problem commonly encountered by traditional RNNs.

**Bidirectional RNNs**: Bidirectional recurrent neural networks (BRNN) use two RNNs that process the same input in opposite directions. These two are often combined, giving the bidirectional LSTM architecture.

## Historical Development

Long short-term memory (LSTM) networks were invented by Hochreiter and Schmidhuber in 1995 and set accuracy records in multiple applications domains.

Based on the search results, here's what I found about graph convolutional networks:

## Overview

The graph convolutional network (GCN) was first introduced by Thomas Kipf and Max Welling in 2017.(no content)GCNs can be understood as a generalization of convolutional neural networks to graph-structured data.

## How They Work

A GCN layer defines a first-order approximation of a localized spectral filter on graphs.(no content)The key design element of GNNs is the use of pairwise message passing, such that graph nodes iteratively update their representations by exchanging information with their neighbors.

## Applications

Graph neural networks (GNN) are specialized artificial neural networks that are designed for tasks whose inputs are graphs. One prominent example is molecular drug design. Each input sample is a graph representation of a molecule, where atoms form the nodes and chemical bonds between atoms form the edges.

## Limitations and Challenges

Stacking many MPNN layers may cause issues such as oversmoothing and oversquashing. Oversmoothing refers to the issue of node representations becoming indistinguishable. Oversquashing refers to the bottleneck that is created by squeezing long-range dependencies into fixed-size representations.

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about social media:

## Definition and Purpose

Social media refers to "forms of electronic communication (such as websites for social networking and microblogging) through which users create online communities to share information, ideas, personal messages, and other content (such as videos)."(no content)Social media is used to share memories, form friendships, build communities and learn.

## Key Features and Functions

These interactive platforms allow individuals, communities, businesses, and organizations to share, co-create, discuss, participate in, and modify user-generated or self-curated content.(no content)They may be used to promote people, companies, products, and ideas, and social media can be used to consume, publish, or share news.

## Popular Platforms

Popular social media platforms with over 100 million registered users include Twitter, Facebook, WeChat, ShareChat, Instagram, Pinterest, QZone, Weibo, VK, Tumblr, Baidu Tieba, Threads and LinkedIn.(no content)Other popular platforms that are sometimes referred to as social media services include YouTube, Letterboxd, QQ, Quora, Telegram, WhatsApp, Signal, LINE, Snapchat, Viber, Reddit, Discord, and TikTok.

## Global Usage

As of 2023, as many as 4.76 billion people used social media, some 59% of the global population.

## Differences from Traditional Media

Social media outlets operate in a dialogic transmission system (many sources to many receivers) while traditional media operate under a monologic transmission model (one source to many receivers).

Links: [{"title":"Rumor Scanner Bangladesh - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rumor_Scanner_Bangladesh"},{"title":"Rumor - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rumor"},{"title":"List of fact-checking websites - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_fact-checking_websites"},{"title":"Rumor control center - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rumor_control_center"},{"title":"Pheme (project) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pheme_(project)"},{"title":"Rumor (disambiguation) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rumor_(disambiguation)"},{"title":"Rumor spread in social network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rumor_spread_in_social_network"},{"title":"Rumors (disambiguation) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rumors_(song)"},{"title":"Lie detection - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lie_detection"},{"title":"The Rumour (TV series) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Rumour_(TV_series)"}]

Based on the web search results, here's an overview of rumor detection:

## What is a Rumor?

A rumor is an unverified piece of information circulating among people, especially without solid evidence.(no content)Rumors are often discussed with regard to misinformation and disinformation (the former often seen as simply false and the latter seen as deliberately false).

## Rumor Detection and Control

Rumor control centers identify, investigate and mitigate potentially disruptive rumors, capable of driving a cycle of harmful escalation.(no content)These centers often operate call centers and respond to crisis situations such as terrorist attacks, natural disasters, or civil disturbances.

The rumor control process involves three main phases: identifying the most recent rumors in circulation through trained "rumor agents", establishing the truth and/or falsehood of the rumors, and replacing inaccurate reports with reliable information.

## Rumor Detection in Digital Contexts

The Pheme project aims to analyze content in real time and determine how accurate the claims made in it are, using language analysis and the spread of information through networks as well as spatial and temporal context to build a real-time lie detector for social media.(no content)The rampant spread of misinformation and rumors on online social networks has raised significant concerns, and the study of rumor dynamics and development of effective mitigation strategies have become crucial areas of research.

Based on the web search results, here's an overview of rumor detection:

## What is a Rumor?

A rumor is an unverified piece of information circulating among people, especially without solid evidence.(no content)Rumors are often discussed with regard to misinformation and disinformation (the former often seen as simply false and the latter seen as deliberately false).

## Rumor Detection and Control

Rumor control centers identify, investigate and mitigate potentially disruptive rumors, capable of driving a cycle of harmful escalation.(no content)These centers often operate call centers and respond to crisis situations such as terrorist attacks, natural disasters, or civil disturbances.

The rumor control process involves three main phases: identifying the most recent rumors in circulation through trained "rumor agents", establishing the truth and/or falsehood of the rumors, and replacing inaccurate reports with reliable information.

## Rumor Detection in Digital Contexts

The Pheme project aims to analyze content in real time and determine how accurate the claims made in it are, using language analysis and the spread of information through networks as well as spatial and temporal context to build a real-time lie detector for social media.(no content)The rampant spread of misinformation and rumors on online social networks has raised significant concerns, and the study of rumor dynamics and development of effective mitigation strategies have become crucial areas of research.

Links: [{"title":"Deep learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deep_learning"},{"title":"Deep reinforcement learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deep_reinforcement_learning"},{"title":"Transformer (deep learning) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Transformer_(deep_learning)"},{"title":"Neural network (machine learning) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Neural_network_(machine_learning)"},{"title":"Machine learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Machine_learning"},{"title":"Layer (deep learning) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Layer_(deep_learning)"},{"title":"Fine-tuning (deep learning) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fine-tuning_(deep_learning)"},{"title":"Category:Deep learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Deep_learning"},{"title":"History of artificial neural networks - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_artificial_neural_networks"},{"title":"Topological deep learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Topological_deep_learning"}]

Based on the search results, here's a comprehensive overview of deep learning:

## What is Deep Learning?

In machine learning, deep learning focuses on utilizing multilayered neural networks to perform tasks such as classification, regression, and representation learning.(no content)The field takes inspiration from biological neuroscience and revolves around stacking artificial neurons into layers and "training" them to process data.

## Key Characteristics

The adjective "deep" refers to the use of multiple layers (ranging from three to several hundred or thousands) in the network.(no content)Fundamentally, deep learning refers to a class of machine learning algorithms in which a hierarchy of layers is used to transform input data into a progressively more abstract and composite representation.

## How It Works

In the deep learning approach, features are not hand-crafted and the model discovers useful feature representations from the data automatically. For example, in an image recognition model, the raw input may be an image (represented as a tensor of pixels). The first representational layer may attempt to identify basic shapes such as lines and circles, the second layer may compose and encode arrangements of edges, the third layer may encode a nose and eyes, and the fourth layer may recognize that the image contains a face.

## Common Architectures and Applications

Some common deep learning network architectures include fully connected networks, deep belief networks, recurrent neural networks, convolutional neural networks, generative adversarial networks, transformers, and neural radiance fields. These architectures have been applied to fields including computer vision, speech recognition, natural language processing, machine translation, bioinformatics, drug design, medical image analysis, climate science, material inspection.

Here are the search results for **information propagation networks**:

## Key Concepts

The search results reveal several related concepts and applications:

### Propagation Algorithms

Label propagation is a semi-supervised algorithm in machine learning that assigns labels to previously unlabeled data points.(no content)Belief propagation, also known as sum–product message passing, is a message-passing algorithm for performing inference on graphical models, such as Bayesian networks and Markov random fields.

### Network Science Framework

Network science is an academic field which studies complex networks such as telecommunication networks, computer networks, biological networks, cognitive and semantic networks, and social networks, considering distinct elements or actors represented by nodes (or vertices) and the connections between the elements or actors as links (or edges).

### Information Spread in Networks

Centrality measures are essential when a network analysis has to answer questions such as: "Which nodes in the network should be targeted to ensure that a message or information spreads to all or most nodes in the network?"

### Temporal Propagation

The arrow of time is preserved so that the contribution of activity is asymmetric in the direction of information propagation. This is relevant when analyzing how information flows through networks over time.

The results cover propagation in various contexts—from machine learning algorithms to biological networks to social networks—all studying how information, labels, or signals spread through connected systems.

Links: [{"title":"Neural network (machine learning) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Neural_network_(machine_learning)"},{"title":"Neural network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Neural_network"},{"title":"Physical neural network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Physical_neural_network"},{"title":"Convolutional neural network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Convolutional_neural_network"},{"title":"Neural network (biology) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Biological_neural_network"},{"title":"Graph neural network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Graph_neural_network"},{"title":"History of artificial neural networks - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_artificial_neural_networks"},{"title":"Energy-based generative neural network","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Energy-based_generative_neural_network"},{"title":"Feedback neural network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Feedback_neural_network"},{"title":"File:Artificial Neural Network.gif","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Artificial_Neural_Network.gif"}]

I've completed a web search for "neural network" and found comprehensive information about neural networks. Here's a summary of the key findings:

## Definition and Basics

A neural network consists of connected units or nodes called artificial neurons, which loosely model the neurons in the brain.(no content)Signals travel from the first layer (the input layer) to the last layer (the output layer), possibly passing through multiple intermediate layers (hidden layers).

## Applications

Neural networks are used to solve problems in artificial intelligence, and have thereby found applications in many disciplines, including predictive modeling, adaptive control, facial recognition, handwriting recognition, general game playing, and generative AI.

## How They Work

Neural networks are typically trained through empirical risk minimization, which is based on the idea of optimizing the network's parameters to minimize the difference between predicted output and actual target values. Gradient-based methods such as backpropagation are usually used to estimate the parameters of the network.

## Types of Neural Networks

Some specific types include:
- A convolutional neural network (CNN) is a type of feedforward neural network that learns features via filter (or kernel) optimization, and has been applied to process and make predictions from many different types of data including text, images and audio.
- Graph neural networks (GNN) are specialized artificial neural networks that are designed for tasks whose inputs are graphs.

The search results provide detailed information about neural network architecture, training methods, history, and various specialized types used in modern machine learning and AI applications.

I've completed a web search for "neural network" and found comprehensive information about neural networks. Here's a summary of the key findings:

## Definition and Basics

A neural network consists of connected units or nodes called artificial neurons, which loosely model the neurons in the brain.(no content)Signals travel from the first layer (the input layer) to the last layer (the output layer), possibly passing through multiple intermediate layers (hidden layers).

## Applications

Neural networks are used to solve problems in artificial intelligence, and have thereby found applications in many disciplines, including predictive modeling, adaptive control, facial recognition, handwriting recognition, general game playing, and generative AI.

## How They Work

Neural networks are typically trained through empirical risk minimization, which is based on the idea of optimizing the network's parameters to minimize the difference between predicted output and actual target values. Gradient-based methods such as backpropagation are usually used to estimate the parameters of the network.

## Types of Neural Networks

Some specific types include:
- A convolutional neural network (CNN) is a type of feedforward neural network that learns features via filter (or kernel) optimization, and has been applied to process and make predictions from many different types of data including text, images and audio.
- Graph neural networks (GNN) are specialized artificial neural networks that are designed for tasks whose inputs are graphs.

The search results provide detailed information about neural network architecture, training methods, history, and various specialized types used in modern machine learning and AI applications.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

message_text:
1. [completed] Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. [completed] List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. [completed] For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. [completed] Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: name: Use the Wikipedia article title, relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes), entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other, wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/), relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. [in_progress] Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. [pending] If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

Web search results for query: "convolutional neural network"

Links: [{"title":"Convolutional neural network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Convolutional_neural_network"},{"title":"Talk:Convolutional neural network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Convolutional_neural_network"},{"title":"Region Based Convolutional Neural Networks - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Region_Based_Convolutional_Neural_Networks"},{"title":"Graph neural network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Graph_neural_network"},{"title":"Convolutional layer - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Convolutional_layer"},{"title":"Kunihiko Fukushima - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kunihiko_Fukushima"},{"title":"Neural network (machine learning) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Neural_network_(machine_learning)"},{"title":"Energy-based generative neural network","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Energy-based_generative_neural_network"},{"title":"Category:Neural network architectures - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Neural_network_architectures"},{"title":"History of artificial neural networks - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_artificial_neural_networks"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about convolutional neural networks:

## Overview

A convolutional neural network (CNN) is a type of feedforward neural network that learns features via filter (or kernel) optimization.(no content)This type of deep learning network has been applied to process and make predictions from many different types of data including text, images and audio.

## Architecture

A convolutional neural network consists of an input layer, hidden layers and an output layer. In a convolutional neural network, the hidden layers include one or more layers that perform convolutions.(no content)This is followed by other layers such as pooling layers, fully connected layers, and normalization layers.

## How They Work

As the convolution kernel slides along the input matrix for the layer, the convolution operation generates a feature map, which in turn contributes to the input of the next layer.(no content)Convolution reduces the number of free parameters, allowing the network to be deeper. For example, using a 5 × 5 tiling region, each with the same shared weights, requires only 25 neurons. Using shared weights means there are many fewer parameters, which helps avoid the vanishing gradients and exploding gradients problems seen during backpropagation in earlier neural networks.

## Historical Background

The origin of the CNN architecture is the "neocognitron" introduced by Kunihiko Fukushima in 1980. It was inspired by work of Hubel and Wiesel in the 1950s and 1960s which showed that cat visual cortices contain neurons that individually respond to small regions of the visual field.

## Modern Applications

Convolutional layers are some of the primary building blocks of convolutional neural networks (CNNs), a class of neural network most commonly applied to images, video, audio, and other data that have the property of uniform translational symmetry.
